title-group.article-title: Wordsworth, Panoramas, and the Prospect of London

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 The Trustees of Boston University

Wilcox's comments: "Not just realism but ultra-realism was needed for panorama painting. The spectator had to be fooled into imagining that what he was looking at was not mere paint applied to canvas but reality itself" (Panoramania 46).

Barrell points out the "almost universal" acceptance of the view that the highef branches of painting were "obliged to idealise nature" by abstracting from partic- ulars; the painter was to adapt the appearances of things "so as to conform with an ideal image in his own mind" (86).
